sen.j: 衣冠（いかん）は平安時代以降の貴族や官人の宮中での勤務服。
sen.e: Ikan is the work cloths of nobles and government officials in the Imperial Court after the Heian period.
Ikan is the work clothes of nobles and government officials in the Imperial Court after the Heian period.
Ikan is the work clothes of nobles and government officials in the Imperial Court after the Heian period.

sen.j: もともと宮中での勤務服は朝服及び、朝服を改造した束帯であった。
sen.e: Originally, work cloths were chofuku (cloths which the people who come to work at the court on a regular basis wear) and sokutai (traditional ceremonial court dress), which was converted from chofuku.

Originally, work clothes at the Imperial Court were chofuku (clothes for the people who come to work at the court on a regular basis wear) and sokutai (traditional ceremonial court dress), which was converted from chofuku.
sen.cmt: cloths→clothes,”宮中での”の部分を挿入しました。
sen.e: Originally, work clothes at the Imperial Court were chofuku (clothes for the people who come to work at the court on a regular basis wear) and sokutai (traditional ceremonial court dress), which was converted from chofuku.

sen.j: しかし束帯は石帯で体を締め付けるなどして窮屈であったため、宿直（とのい）には不向きであった。
sen.e: However, sokutai was constrictive because it was sekitai (leather belt), so it was not suitable for Tonoi (night guard).
However, sokutai was not suitable for Tonoi (night guard) since it was sekitai (leather belt) and hence constrictive.
sen.cmt: 文中のオーダーを修正し、流れをより自然にしました。
sen.e: However, sokutai was not suitable for Tonoi (night guard) since it was sekitai (leather belt) and hence constrictive.

sen.j: そこで、「宿直装束」として衣冠が生まれた。
sen.e: Therefore, Ikan was created as 'Tonoi sozoku' (a costume which Tonoi, the night guards wear).
Therefore, ikan was created as 'Tonoi sozoku' (a costume of Tonoi, the night guards wear).
sen.cmt: Ikan→ikan, costume which Tonoi → costume of Tonoi と修正しました。
sen.e: Therefore, ikan was created as 'Tonoi sozoku' (a costume of Tonoi, the night guards wear).

sen.j: 基本的な構成は束帯と同じであるが、束帯の下着類を大幅に省いているのが特徴。
sen.e: The basic structure of ikan is same as sokutai, but it is characterized by considerably simplified underclothing.
The basic structure of ikan is the same as sokutai, but charactalistically, its underclothing is drastically simplified from sokutai.
sen.cmt: same →the same,後半部分をよりスムースに修正しました。
sen.e: The basic structure of ikan is the same as sokutai, but charactalistically, its underclothing is drastically simplified from sokutai.

sen.j: 束帯では和服用語集を締めるのに石帯を使用するが、衣冠では共布のくけ紐で袍を締め、袴もゆったりとした指貫とした。
sen.e: While sekitai is worn over ho (round-necked robe worn by members of nobility and the imperial court) in sokutai, in ikan, kukehimo (narrow sausages of silk cloth) of common cloth is worn over ho, and hakama was sashinuki (pleated trousers for formal wear)
sen.cmt: 原文には (和服用語集) とありますが、リンク先の単語のようです。ウェブで確認すると用語が「袍」となっており、本来はこちらの用語を使用していると思われますので、こちらを訳出しました。
sen.e: While sekitai is worn over ho (round-necked robe worn by members of nobility and the Imperial Court) in sokutai, in ikan, kukehimo (narrow sausages of silk cloth) of common cloth is worn over ho, and hakama was loose sashinuki (pleated trousers for formal wear).
sen.cmt: Imperial court→Imperial Court,loose を挿入して補強し、ピリオドを挿入しました。
sen.e: While sekitai is worn over ho (round-necked robe worn by members of nobility and the Imperial Court) in sokutai, in ikan, kukehimo (narrow sausages of silk cloth) of common cloth is worn over ho, and hakama was loose sashinuki (pleated trousers for formal wear).

sen.j: 着用するには、まず下着を着て指貫をはき、単、袍を着る。
sen.e: To wear ikan, you first wear underclothing, then sashinuki, hitoe (a single layer of kimono), and ho.
To wear ikan, you first wear underwear, then sashinuki, hitoe (a single layer of kimono), and ho.
To wear ikan, you first wear underwear, then sashinuki, hitoe (a single layer of kimono), and ho.

sen.j: 垂纓の冠をかぶり、扇を持つ。
sen.e: Then, you wear suiei no kanmuri (a kind of cap included into official uniform which is a type of having Ei, an attachment of cap hanging back of head) and hold a folding fan.
Then, you wear suiei no kanmuri (a kind of cap included into official uniform which is a type of having Ei, an attachment of cap hanging back of head) and hold a folding fan.
Then, you wear suiei no kanmuri (a kind of cap included into official uniform which is a type of having Ei, an attachment of cap hanging back of head) and hold a folding fan.

sen.j: 神詣以外の衣冠着用時に笏は持たない。
sen.e: You hold saku (mace) only when you wear ikan to visit a shrine.
You hold shaku (mace) only when you wear ikan to visit a shrine.
You hold shaku (mace) only when you wear ikan to visit a shrine.

sen.j: また、太刀を佩用する場合でも平緒は用いない。
sen.e: In addition, when you carry sword, hirao (cord of sword) is not used.
In addition, when you carry a sword, hirao (cord of sword) is not used.
In addition, when you carry a sword, hirao (cord of sword) is not used.

sen.j: なお、束帯とは違い衣冠には文官と武官の区別が無く、武官であっても縫腋袍を用いる。
sen.e: Unlike sokutai, there is no difference between ikan for civil officers and military officers, and military officers also wear hoeki no ho (robe with a round collar, stitched sides and a ran, worn by the emperor and high-ranking officials).

Unlike sokutai, there is no difference between ikan for civil officers and military officers, and military officers also wear hoeki no ho (robe with a round collar, stitched sides and a ran, worn by the emperor and high-ranking officials).
sen.cmt: スペースの修正をしました。
sen.e: Unlike sokutai, there is no difference between ikan for civil officers and military officers, and military officers also wear hoeki no ho (robe with a round collar, stitched sides and a ran, worn by the emperor and high-ranking officials).

sen.j: 色目・紋様には身分によって決まりがあった。
sen.e: Color combinations and patterns indicated one's rank.
Rules about color combinations and patterns indicated ranks.
sen.cmt: 文脈より修正しました。
sen.e: Rules about color combinations and patterns indicated ranks.

tit.j: 時代の移り変わりと共に
tit.cmt: Change→Changes,with times→over time と修正しました。

sen.j: 時代を経るにつれて束帯は儀式用の服装となり、衣冠は宮中での勤務服として定着した。
sen.e: Over time, sokutai became ritual accouterments and ikan became popular as the work cloths in the Imperial Court.
Over time, sokutai became the ritual accouterments and ikan became established as the work clothes in the Imperial Court.
sen.cmt: the を挿入しました。スペースを修正しました。popular→established,cloths→clothes と修正しました。
sen.e: Over time, sokutai became the ritual accouterments and ikan became established as the work clothes in the Imperial Court.

sen.j: また、衣冠姿であれば参内（御所への出入り）に勅許を得る必要は無かった。
sen.e: In addition, you didn't have to obtain imperial sanction for sandai (a visit to the Imperial Palace) if you are wearing ikan.
In addition, you didn't have to obtain imperial sanction for sandai (a visit to the Imperial Palace) if you were wearing ikan.
In addition, you didn't have to obtain imperial sanction for sandai (a visit to the Imperial Palace) if you were wearing ikan.

sen.j: 近世に宮中の宿直である「内裏小番」の制度が確立すると、儀式以外の日常の勤務服として直衣・衣冠が一般化した。
sen.e: As the 'Dairi koban' (night guard in the Imperial court) system was established in the early-modern times, noshi (everyday clothes for nobles) and ikan became popular as daily work cloths other than ceremonies.

As the 'Dairi koban' (night guard in the Imperial Court) system was established in the early-modern times, noshi (everyday clothes for nobles) and ikan became common as daily work clothes other than ceremonies.
sen.cmt: Imperial court→Imperial Court,popular→common,cloths→clothes と修正しました。
sen.e: As the 'Dairi koban' (night guard in the Imperial Court) system was established in the early-modern times, noshi (everyday clothes for nobles) and ikan became common as daily work clothes other than ceremonies.

sen.j: 江戸時代には、全くの平常の出仕には衣冠・直衣の下に単を用いず白小袖の上に直接袍を着たり、指貫に代えて切袴の「指袴（さしこ）」を着たりすることもあった。
sen.e: In the Edo period, they would wear ho directly over shiro kosode (a kind of white underwear) without wearing hitoe under ikan or noshi, or 'sashiko' (a kind of quilted trousers) or kiri-hakama (short fringe hakama) was worn instead of sashinuki for ordinary serving.

In the Edo period, they sometimes wore ho directly over shiro kosode (a kind of white underwear) without wearing hitoe under ikan or noshi, or 'sashiko' (a kind of quilted trousers) or kiri-bakama (short fringe hakama) was worn instead of sashinuki for ordinary serving.
sen.cmt: would wear→sometimes wore,kiri-hakama→kiri-bakama と修正しました。
sen.e: In the Edo period, they sometimes wore ho directly over shiro kosode (a kind of white underwear) without wearing hitoe under ikan or noshi, or 'sashiko' (a kind of quilted trousers) or kiri-bakama (short fringe hakama) was worn instead of sashinuki for ordinary serving.

sen.j: そのため単を着用しての衣冠姿を「衣冠単（いかんたん・いかんひとえ）」とも言う。
sen.e: Therefore, ikan clothing wearing hitoe was also called 'ikantan' or 'ikanhitoe' (kimono and ancient head-dress with a layer).
Therefore, ikan clothing wearing hitoe is also called 'ikantan' or 'ikanhitoe' (kimono and ancient head-dress with a layer).
sen.cmt: was→ is と修正しました。
sen.e: Therefore, ikan clothing wearing hitoe is also called 'ikantan' or 'ikanhitoe' (kimono and ancient head-dress with a layer).

sen.j: 近世の公家日記には、指袴で出仕中急に天皇に御礼言上する必要が生じたので指貫に着替えたといった記事もみられる。
sen.e: In kuge-nikki (noblemen's diaries) in the early-modern times, articles that describes someone wearing sashiko while serving changed his clothes to sashinuki because he suddenly needed to say thank you to the emperor.

In kuge-nikki (noblemen's diaries) in the early-modern times, there are articles that describe someone wearing sashiko while serving who suddenly needed to change his clothes to sashinuki to say thank the emperor.
sen.cmt: there are を挿入しました。describes→describe,文中後半を文脈より修正しました。
sen.e: In kuge-nikki (noblemen's diaries) in the early-modern times, there are articles that describe someone wearing sashiko while serving who suddenly needed to change his clothes to sashinuki to say thank the emperor.

sen.j: この時代でも御会始（歌会始）や御楽始（雅楽始）など、政務ではない儀式や私家の元服などの儀式には単や衣（あこめの類）を重ね、指貫をつけた正式な衣冠・直衣を着用した。
sen.e: Even in this period, in ceremonies that are not government affairs such as New Year Imperial Poetry Reading Parties or New Year Gagaku (ancient Japanese court dance and music) Recitals or private ceremonies such as genpuku (celebrate one's coming of age), they would wear official ikan or noshi layering hitoe or kinu and sashinuki.

Even in this period, in ceremonies that were not government affairs such as New Year Imperial Poetry Reading Parties or New Year Gagaku (ancient Japanese court dance and music) Recitals or private ceremonies such as genpuku (celebrate one's coming of age), they wore official ikan or noshi layering hitoe or kinu and sashinuki.
sen.cmt: are→were,would wear→wore と修正しました。
sen.e: Even in this period, in ceremonies that were not government affairs such as New Year Imperial Poetry Reading Parties or New Year Gagaku (ancient Japanese court dance and music) Recitals or private ceremonies such as genpuku (celebrate one's coming of age), they wore official ikan or noshi layering hitoe or kinu and sashinuki.

sen.j: なお、明治5年に宮中や官界では正装・礼装を洋服に改めたため、現在では、宮中祭祀・儀式の際に諸皇族方や掌典職が祭服として着用するほかは、神社界の神職が正装として衣冠を着用する。
sen.e: Since 1872, European clothes have been used as formal attire and a ceremonial dresses in the imperial court and the government, so nowadays, ikan is used by Shinto priests in shrines as formal attire, as well as imperial families and ceremonial staffs wear ikan as ceremonial attire in court rituals and ceremonies.

Since 1872, European clothes have become the formal attire and ceremonial dresses in the Imperial Court and the government, so now ikan is used by Shinto priests in shrines as formal attire, besides the imperial families and ceremonial staffs wear ikan as ceremonial attire in court rituals and ceremonies.
sen.cmt: have been used as→have become the,a ceremonial dresses→ceremonial dress,imperial court→Imperial Court,so nowadays→so now,as well as→besides the と修正しました。
sen.e: Since 1872, European clothes have become the formal attire and ceremonial dresses in the Imperial Court and the government, so now ikan is used by Shinto priests in shrines as formal attire, besides the imperial families and ceremonial staffs wear ikan as ceremonial attire in court rituals and ceremonies.

sen.j: 中世の文献では「衣冠正しき」姿というように、束帯・衣冠を厳密に分けずに、単に貴人の正装の意味でこの言葉を使うこともある。
sen.e: In literature in the medieval period, sokutai and ikan were not strictly distinguished, but the word 'ikan' may be used to simply mean formal attire of nobles as in the 'ikan tadashiki' (properly wearing ikan).

In literature in the medieval period, sokutai and ikan were not precisely distinguished, but the word 'ikan' may be used to simply mean formal attire of nobles as in the 'ikan tadashiki' (properly wearing ikan).

In literature in the medieval period, sokutai and ikan were not precisely distinguished, but the word 'ikan' may be used to simply mean formal attire of nobles as in the 'ikan tadashiki' (properly wearing ikan).

sen.j: 日記や故実書では厳密な使い方が普通で、歌論書や寺社縁起などではあいまいな用法が多い。
sen.e: In diaries and writings on records of the past, the word is usually used to mean the strict meaning, and in documents of theory about classic Japanese poem and legends of temples and shrines, the word is often used in the vague way.

In diaries and writings on records of the past, the word is usually used strictly, and in documents of theory about classic Japanese poem and legends of temples and shrines, the word is often used in the vague way.
sen.cmt: to mean the strict meaning→strictly と修正しました。
sen.e: In diaries and writings on records of the past, the word is usually used strictly, and in documents of theory about classic Japanese poem and legends of temples and shrines, the word is often used in the vague way.

sen.j: また、俗な表現として袍を着用した姿の総称を「衣冠束帯」と呼ぶことがあるが、装束の構成や着用する場面に於いて、本来は衣冠と束帯は厳密に区分される。
sen.e: In common parlance, figures wearing ho is sometimes collectively calls 'ikan-sokutai,' but fundamentally, ikan and sokutai should be strictly distinguished by the structure of the shozoku (costume) and occasions in which they are worn.

Also in common parlance, general term of the figures wearing ho is sometimes called 'ikan-sokutai,' but fundamentally, ikan and sokutai should be strictly distinguished by the structure of the shozoku (costume) and occasions in which they are worn.
sen.cmt: 文中前半を文脈にそって修正しました。
sen.e: Also in common parlance, general term of the figures wearing ho is sometimes called 'ikan-sokutai,' but fundamentally, ikan and sokutai should be strictly distinguished by the structure of the shozoku (costume) and occasions in which they are worn.

sen.j: 一説には平安中期以降、服制が曖昧になり、衣冠や直衣を束帯の代用とした「衣冠の束帯」「直衣の束帯」という例があり、前者の語から接助詞の「の」が省かれて誤用され、定着してしまった結果であるとされる。
sen.e: One theory says that uniforms became lax in and after mid Heian period and there were examples of 'ikan no sokutai' and 'noshi no sokutai' where ikan or noshi was used as an alternative of sokutai, and the particle'no' was omitted from the former phrase, which was misused and became popular.

One theory says that uniforms became lax in and after the mid Heian period and there were examples of 'ikan no sokutai' and 'noshi no sokutai' where ikan or noshi was used as an alternative of sokutai, and the particle 'no' was omitted from the former phrase, which was misused and then became established.
sen.cmt: スペースの修正、mid Heian period→the mid Heian period,and became popular→then became established と修正しました。
sen.e: One theory says that uniforms became lax in and after the mid Heian period and there were examples of 'ikan no sokutai' and 'noshi no sokutai' where ikan or noshi was used as an alternative of sokutai, and the particle 'no' was omitted from the former phrase, which was misused and then became established.

sen.j: ただし、公家の日記に「直衣束帯」などの表記がある場合も、丁寧に解釈すると「直衣を着た者や束帯を着た者がいる」の意味である場合もあり、平安中期には「直衣束帯」という装束（直衣の袍・表袴・石帯・下襲等より成る）があったことも知られるなど、上記の説については厳密な検証が必要と思われる。
sen.e: However, when there are expressions such as 'noshi sokutai' in kuge diaries, they may mean 'there are someone in noshi and someone in sokutai' when you closely read them, and it is known there were shozoku called 'noshi sokutai' (composed of noshi no ho (round-necked robe), ue no hakama (outer trousers), sekitai, shitagasane (long inner robe), etc. in mid Heian period, so the above theory requires rigorous verification.

However, when there are expressions such as 'noshi sokutai' in kuge diaries, they may mean 'there is someone in noshi or someone in sokutai' when you closely read them, and it is known there were shozoku called 'noshi sokutai' (composed of noshi no ho [round-necked robe]), ue no hakama (outer trousers), sekitai, shitagasane (long inner robe), etc. in the mid Heian period, so the theories above require rigorous verification.
sen.cmt: and→or,カッコ部分を修正しました。mid Heian period→the mid Heian period,above theory requires→theories above require と修正しました。
sen.e: However, when there are expressions such as 'noshi sokutai' in kuge diaries, they may mean 'there is someone in noshi or someone in sokutai' when you closely read them, and it is known there were shozoku called 'noshi sokutai' (composed of noshi no ho [round-necked robe]), ue no hakama (outer trousers), sekitai, shitagasane (long inner robe), etc. in the mid Heian period, so the theories above require rigorous verification.
